Nanostructured Nb doped TiO2 were prepared by a novel Sol-Gel method using new N‐methyldiethanolamine‐modified precursors of Ti (IV) and Nb(V). Co-hydrolysis of Ti(IV) and Nb(V) precursors in suitable ratio resulted in the introduction of atomically dispersed Nb cation, along with the formation of small Nb oxo clusters homogenously dispersed within the TiO2 matrix. Characterizations showed a progressive decrease of the crystallinity as well as an increase in the defects and the BET surface areas of the TiO2 nanoparticles with the Nb doping. Upon Nb doping, gas phase calorimetry of NH3 and CO2 adsorption, evidenced the acidity but also the basicity increase. The aqueous phase dihydroxyacetone conversion increased significantly over Nb/TiO2 as compared to undoped TiO2. However, upon increasing the Nb doping, the base-catalyzed pathway, which forms hexoses from DHA, became the prevailing mechanism at the expense of the usual acid-catalyzed pathway leading to formation of Pyruvaldehyde. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Nb doped TiO2 Water tolerant acid-base catalysts Metal aminoalkoxide Sol-Gel precursors DHA transformation Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Lignocellulosic biomass is one of the cheapest sustainable sources of renewable raw materials for obtaining value-added chemicals, energy and fuels. Within this scenario, the chemical catalytic routes for lignocellulosic biomass valorization have received much attention over the past years in response to the economic and environment issues [1–5]. In this regard, the catalytic transformation of dihydroxyacetone (DHA) into lactic acid (LA) was seen by many researchers as an interesting model reaction for designing efficient acid heterogeneous catalysts to produce commodity chemicals from lignocellulosic biomass in water [6–9]. Indeed, lactic acid itself has been targeted as an important platform molecule being widely used in pharmaceutical, food, cosmetic, solvents and polymers industries [10]. The main process for lactic acid (LA) production is through microbial fermentation of pentoses or hexoses in aqueous solutions having several drawbacks concerning the efficiency of the process (low concentration of LA combined to difficult LA separation and purification because salts of LA are produced instead of LA due to the neutralization of the fermentation media which requires a neutral pH) [11]. Among the heterogeneous catalysts, those based on supported and unsupported transition metal oxides with Br∅nsted/Lewis acid sites, zeolites, metal phosphates, molecular sieves, metal salts, γ-Al2O3, ZrO2, TiO2 and Nb2O5 have been evaluated in the transformation of DHA into lactic acid [7,8,12–18]. Besides being highly active, the acidic transition metal oxides are cost effective and exhibit several other benefits, notably an improved stability in water for some of them. Particularly, TiO2 and Nb2O5 catalysts are very versatile for the DHA transformation, which display Lewis and/or Brønsted acid sites and water tolerant properties, [16–18]. Much interest has been given to their water-tolerant Lewis acidity, which promotes lactic acid formation from DHA. In a very recent work dealing with the investigation of the acid and base properties of a series of commercial TiO2 of various origin using usual gas phase microcalorimetry of CO2 and NH3 adsorption, and the model reaction of DHA conversion in water, we have shown that the original acid/base balance of the panel of TiO2 samples varied strongly among the samples, the rutile TiO2 presenting the most basic surface [9,19]. More importantly, the TiO2 base sites were shown to be water tolerant which drove efficiently the DHA conversion into hexoses formation via triose aldolic condensation [9]. Thus, two parallel pathways are possible depending on the presence of water tolerant: i) Br∅nsted/Lewis acidity leading to lactic acid formation or ii) basic sites leading to hexoses formation. The occurrence of these two parallel pathways was confirmed using pure acid and base catalysts namely NbOH and MgAlO hydrotalcite [9]. In the continuity of these studies, the design of mixed oxides, particularly those based on niobium and titanium oxides, could allow to obtain water tolerant and stable materials with tunable acid-base properties. These new materials with controlled water tolerant acid-base properties would have high potential for biosourced substrates conversion in water. Pioneering work has already been done in this direction. Nakajima et al. have demonstrated that Nb2O5 supported on TiO2 holds more promising catalytic properties than their parent unsupported oxides [20]. The atomically dispersed Nb- and Pb-TiO2 nanoparticles have been successively obtained throughout an innovative sol-gel approach, resulting in excellent homogeneous dispersion of the dopant metal oxides within TiO2 at atomic level and enhanced surface area [21]. In the present work, the effects of increasing amounts of the Nb dopant within TiO2 framework have been addressed to control the original acid-base properties. This was accomplished by probing the solids in gas phase and investigating their water tolerance thanks to the model reaction of DHA conversion into products throughout either an acid catalyzed (Pyruvaldehyde (PA) and Lactic acid (LA)) or a base catalyzed mechanism (hexoses and cellobiose). 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Ti(OEt)4 and Nb(OEt)5 were purchased from Strem Chemicals, and stored under vacuum prior to use. Methyl diethanolamine was purchased from Aldrich and stored under argon, without further purifying. Analytical grade ethanol (>99%) was obtained from Carlo Erba and used as received. Anhydrous solvents such as toluene, diethyl-ether and n-hexane were obtained by solvent purification. The dihydroxyacetone reactant was used as received, being supplied by Sigma-Aldrich. 2.2 Synthesis of the catalysts The Nb-doped TiO2 catalysts were synthesized following the protocol of Mishra et al. [21], using new metallic precursors with N-methyldiethanolamine (mdeaH2), which is an important modifier in sol-gel method [22]. For brevity, only the synthesis of TiO2 doped with 20 wt% of Nb (denoted as 20-Nb/TiO2) is described here. Firstly, 45 mmol of N‐methyldiethanolamine solution was added drop-wise to a hexane solution (25 mL) containing 45 mmol of Ti(OEt)4. The reaction mixture was continuously stirred for 3 h to form the precursor [Ti(OEt)2(mdea)]. Simultaneously, 9 mmol of N-methyldiethanolamine was added dropwise to a hexane solution (20 mL) containing 9 mmol of Nb(OEt)5 and the obtained solution was stirred for 3 h to form the precursor [Nb(OEt)3(mdea)]. Both solutions were then mixed together and after removing hexane under vacuum, 75 mL of anhydrous isopropanol was added in it. After stirring this solution for 30 min, a hydrolyzing solution containing 0.1 mL of acetic acid in 3 mL of water and 10 mL of isopropanol was added and the obtained reaction mixture was refluxed under stirring for 3 h. The solvent was recovered by distillation with a rotary evaporator and the obtained sol was dried under vacuum at 100 °C for 3 h. Calcination was carried out in static air by heating the sample to 500 °C at a rate of 1 °C/min and maintaining the final temperature for 4 h. Following a similar procedure, other samples with Nb wt% of 7 and 15 were also prepared and denoted as 7-Nb/TiO2 and 15-Nb/TiO2 respectively. 2.3 Characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on the powdered samples in a Bruker D8 Advance A25 diffractometer apparatus using Cu Kα radiation (0.154184 nm) at 50 kV and 35 mA. The XRD patterns were recorded from 10° to 80° at a scan speed of 2°.min−1 with a step size of 0.02° with acquisition of 96 s per step. The XRD patterns were determined in comparison with those of the Joint Committee of Powder Diffraction Standard (JCPDS) database files. Crystal sizes were obtained from Scherer equation from the (101) peak at 2θ= 25° for TiO2 anatase phase. The textural properties parameters were examined through nitrogen physisorption isotherms at − 196 ◦C in a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. Previously, samples were pre-treated for 3 h at 150◦C under 10−3 Torr. The BET multipoint method was used to get surface areas (S BET) from the isotherms. The t-plot, drawn using the Harkins-Jura equation, is exploited to determine the external surface. The Nb dispersion within the TiO2 framework was obtained in a FEI Titan ETEM G2 electron microscope with a HAADF-STEM apparatus at 300 kV. Raman spectra were recorded in a LabRam (Jobin Yvon) spectrometer instrument at room temperature with a wavelength of excitation laser 514 nm and irradiation power of 10 mW. Original acid-base properties of the solids were investigated by adsorption of NH3 and CO2 monitored by microcalorimetry. Experimental set up consisted of a TianCalvet calorimeter connected to a vacuum glass volumetric equipment to measure, in a parallel way, the differential heat of adsorption of the successive small amounts of probe molecule which was put in contact with the catalysts and its isotherm curve of adsorption. About 0.05 g of sample were heated in a glass cell under vacuum at 150 °C overnight. Subsequently, the sample was cooled down to 80 °C under vacuum and the glass cell was placed into the calorimeter, and small doses of ammonia or carbon dioxide were introduced into the glass cell until the equilibrium pressure was reached. The CO2 adsorption run was performed at 30 °C using the same methodology. Fourier Transformed Infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine measurements were carried out to probe the nature of the acid sites on the surface of catalysts in a Bruker Vector 22 FT-IR spectrophotometer equipped with DTGS detector. Before the measurements, the self-supporting wafer disks (30–50 mg of catalyst, 18 mm diameter) was firstly evacuated in situ at 150 ºC, and then exposed to pyridine vapor pressure at room temperature for 5 min. The desorption was performed by outgassing the samples for 1 h at room temperature and at 150 °C. Afterwards, the IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine were recorded at room temperature after pyridine adsorption and desorption in the abovementioned temperature conditions. 2.4 Catalytic reaction Catalytic evaluations of the conversion of DHA into lactic acid and other products were performed in water using a three-neck Pyrex glass round flask equipped with a water condenser, a temperature sensor and a rubber septum. The reaction conditions (stirring speed, temperature and amount of catalyst) were optimized to avoid diffusion limitations. About 0.1 g of the catalyst and 20 mL of water were placed in a Pyrex glass vessel and heated at 90 °C under agitation using a magnetic stirrer. Once the temperature is stabilized at 90 °C, 0.1 g of DHA (Sigma Aldrich, 1,3-dihydroxyacetone dimer, >97%) was added. This was considered to be the zero time of the reaction. The reaction was then conducted for 4 h and aliquots of the resultant solutions were taken regularly with a syringe through the septum. Before analysis, solutions were diluted 10 − 30 times with water and filtered using a 0.45 µm syringe filter. The solutions were then analyzed by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) (Model Shimadzu Prominence) with a refractive index detector (RID). The substrate and reaction products separation were carried out using a COROGEL 107 H column, at 40 °C, and acidified water (H2SO4 1.7 mM) as mobile phase, with a flow of 0.6 mL.min−1. A HPLC chromatogram of a mixture of products is shown in Fig. S1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural features The XRD pattern of the powder obtained by hydrolysis of the niobium(V) aminoalkoxide precursor, calcined at 500 °C (Fig. S2), exhibits two weak and broad diffraction lines centered at about 2θ= 25° and 55°. This amorphous nature of the material is in good agreement with the previous work, where calcination at higher temperature (600 °C and above) was required to get well-crystallized niobium oxide [23]. XRD patterns of Nb-doped TiO2 samples ( Fig. 1) show the characteristic lines of TiO2 anatase phase, in good agreement with the JCPDS file n° 21–1272. This suggests that the TiO2 is successfully synthesized by sol-gel route and more easily crystallized upon calcination at 500 °C than the pure Nb-based material. No line of Nb oxide can be observed irrespective of its loading %. Also, the relative intensity of the anatase peaks decreases with the opposite trend for their broadness when the Nb amount increases from 7 to 20 wt% within TiO2. This is a clear indication of the lesser degree of crystallization of the doped Nb/TiO2 samples. Increased amounts of dopants seem to reduce the crystallinity of the sample probably due to distortion of the crystalline network. The incorporation of Nb results in a decrease in the crystallinity of the solids, as indicated by the average crystallite sizes values calculated from the Scherrer equation using the diffraction lines of highest intensities, the (101) and (200) planes at 2θ= 25° and 48°, respectively ( Table 1). By increasing the amounts of Nb in the TiO2 structure, the crystal sizes decrease from 10.7 to 7.1 nm in 7-Nb/TiO2 and 20-Nb/TiO2 samples, owing to the occurrence of association defects and dopant-generated defects along the crystal lattice, which cause strain in the crystal lattice and limit the crystal growth. When the wt% of Nb reaches 20, the position of the (101) reflexion line is slightly shifted towards lower 2θ angles (Fig. S3), indicating slightly enlarged d-spacings due to a possible Nb incorporation into TiO2 framework. However, this does not exclude the existence of niobium oxi/hydroxide finely dispersed on TiO2 crystals since we have shown that pure sol-gel Nb-based material remains amorphous upon similar calcination at 500 °C. To further characterize the Nb-doped TiO2 materials structure, Raman measurements were performed. Raman spectrum of the pure Nb oxi/hydroxide obtained by sol-gel synthesis, (Fig. S4), is dominated by a broad band in the 600–800 cm−1 region, which is assigned to the stretching vibration of distorted NbO6 octahedra [24]. The bands below 300 cm−1 were assigned to Nb-O-Nb bending vibrations among others. Similar Raman spectrum was described for commercial hydrated niobium oxide calcined at 500 °C. Fig. 2 depicts the Raman spectra of the Nb doped TiO2 samples. Raman spectra show the main vibrational modes of the TiO2 anatase phase visible at 144 cm−1 (Eg), 195 cm−1 (Eg), 394 cm−1 (B1 g), 514 cm−1 (A1 g + B1 g), and 634 cm−1 (Eg) for all the TiO2-based samples. Vibrations due to Nb oxi/hydroxide or Nb2O5 oxide are not observable. This is consistent with previous XRD results that show the formation of pure anatase phase. Noteworthy, Raman spectra of the Nb/TiO2 samples exhibit a shift of the 144 cm−1 (Eg) vibration towards lower wavenumbers with the simultaneous broadening of the bands, in comparison with the bare TiO2. These Raman shifts and broadenings occur mainly due to the presence of defects in the solid structure. The TiO2 vibration broadening with increasing the Nb content is probably correlated to the decreased crystal sizes of a very defective nanostructured TiO2, in line with the XRD results. The shift of the vibration at 144 cm−1 towards higher wavenumbers is indicative of a higher Ti-oxygen bond order and, therefore, to shorter bond distance. These changes result most likely from the substitution of Ti4+ by Nb5+ giving rise to Nb-O-Ti bond formation. Both XRD and Raman results support the conclusion that the doping of Nb within nanostructured TiO2 via sol-gel synthesis successfully achieved the insertion of Nb ions within the TiO2 framework without evidence of formation of isolated Nb2O5 nanoparticle detectable by XRD or Raman spectroscopy. High resolution STEM images of 15-Nb/TiO2 support only partly this conclusion. Some images show isolated Nb atom inside the TiO2 lattice ( Fig. 3a,b,c) which coexists with small clusters from 0.5 nm to 4 nm (Fig. 3a,c,d). 3.2 Textural properties The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the TiO2 samples are presented in Fig. 4. All the isotherms have a hysteresis loop which is indicative of the presence of mesopores. In addition, the significant nitrogen adsorption at low relative pressure is indicative of the presence of micropores for the Nb doped TiO2. The BET surface areas of Nb doped TiO2 are higher than that of bare TiO2, i.e. 180 m2.g−1 for the doped TiO2 against 49 m2.g−1 for the bare TiO2 sample. These values are in agreement with the reduction of the crystallites’ sizes upon Nb doping as observed by XRD measurements. These data are in favor of interparticle pores. To evaluate the contribution of the microporosity, the t-plot analysis was used to quantify the external surface and the sizes of micropores if present. The BJH method was applied to evaluate the size of mesopores. The t-plots of the bare TiO2 and Nb doped TiO2 are depicted in Fig. 5. We can observe an almost straight line which goes through the origin for the Bare TiO2. This indicates the absence of micropores. Whereas for the Nb doped samples, the t-plot curvature is due to the presence of micropores. For 7-Nb/TiO2, the micropores are in the range of 1.2–1.5 nm. The 15-Nb/TiO2 and 20-NB/TiO2 have larger micropores, roughly from 1.5 nm to 1.8 nm. The external surface areas of the Nb doped TiO2 are around 10 m2.g−1. All the parameters of textural features are summarized in the Table 2. 3.3 Acidity and basicity measurements by probe molecules adsorption in gas phase monitored by FTIR and microcalorimetry 3.3.1 FTIR of Pyridine-adsorption To determine the nature of the acid sites present in the solids, FTIR experiments were performed using pyridine as probe molecule. Fig. 6 shows the Py-FTIR spectra of the undoped and Nb-doped samples after saturation with pyridine vapor at ambient temperature and desorption under vacuum for 1 h at 150 °C. All the pyridine was almost removed after this treatment from the surface of the bare TiO2 sample. In the IR spectrum of pure TiO2 obtained after 1 h vacuum-treatment at 150 ºC (to remove the physisorbed pyridine molecules), vibrations modes of pyridinium species due to Brønsted acid sites are not found (expected at ∼1545 cm−1 and ∼1630 cm−1). Contrary, those of Lewis acid sites are detected as weak bands at 1444 and 1602 cm−1. They are assigned to coordinatively unsaturated Ti4+ present at the TiO2 surface. On the other hand, there is an increase in the intensity and types of vibrations for the TiO2 samples containing Nb dopant with respect to pure TiO2. In the case of the 7-Nb/TiO2 catalyst, bonds formed between the pyridine and Lewis acid sites result in stronger absorption bands. On increasing the niobium amounts further, i.e. for 15-Nb/TiO2 and 20-Nb/TiO2 samples, one can observe a growth in the intensity of the bands related to the Brønsted acid sites, at 1545 cm−1 and 1630–1635 cm−1 together with those ascribed to the Lewis acid sites at 1445 cm−1 and 1610 cm−1. This might be ascribed to the creation of structural hydroxyls groups (Brønsted acid sites) associated to Nb5+ cation dispersed within the TiO2 framework or due to NbxOy clusters exposed at surface, as well as formation of more defects leading to more coordinatively unsaturated Ti4+ or Nb5+ cations, which are accessible at the material surface, as many Lewis acid sites. The increased acidity of the solids is directly related to the addition of niobium in the TiO2 structure. 3.3.2 Microcalorimetry using NH3 as probe molecule Microcalorimetry experiments are generally considered to be reliable analyses for measuring the acid strength and the number of solid acid sites. Thus, the catalysts, whether containing niobium or not, were also analyzed by ammonia adsorption followed by microcalorimetry to determine the total acidity, the acid strength, and the acid strength distribution for the different samples, as well. The TiO2, 7-Nb/TiO2, 15-Nb/TiO2 and 20-Nb/TiO2 samples showed initial differential heat of ammonia adsorption of 78, 147, 156 and 182 kJ.mol−1, respectively, according to Fig. 7, which brings together all the calorimetric curves. These data give the following order of acid strength: 20-Nb/TiO2 > 15-Nb/TiO2 > 7-Nb/TiO2 > TiO2. The TiO2 sample presents the calorimetric curve of a sample with very weak acidity and low number of sites. That is to say, the sample exhibits quite absent NH3 uptake together with low heat of NH3 adsorption. By contrast, 20-Nb/TiO2 and 15-Nb/TiO2 samples show a pseudo plateau up to half NH3 coverage characterized by a mean heat of NH3 adsorption around 140 kJ.mol−1 NH3, before a progressive decrease of the heat of adsorption with increasing doses of the probe molecules adsorption up to the surface saturation around 300 micromol.g−1. This indicates that samples possess a significant higher number of acid sites with a good homogeneity in term of acid strength. Note that 20-Nb/TiO2 exhibits a higher amount of acids sites (280 micromol.g−1), of slightly strongest acid strength compared to 15-Nb/TiO2 (250 micromol.g−1). Besides, 7-Nb/TiO2 sample shows a rapid decrease in the heat of adsorption with the surface coverage, and the total number of acid sites with heat of adsorption higher than 80 kJ.mol−1 is only of 25 micromol.g−1. This cannot be correlated with its textural properties since all the Nb doped samples have equivalent BET surface areas, around 180 m2.g−1. This suggests that the low amount of Nb is at the origin of the slight acidity enhancement. The overall results of calorimetry of NH3 adsorption suit well with the results of FTIR of pyridine adsorption. Table 3 summarizes the acidic features of the TiO2-based samples deduced from the calorimetric studies. Clearly, the increased amounts of acid sites is caused by the extent of Nb doping as well as the acid strengths, possibly linked to the appearance of Br∅nsted acid sites as evidenced by FTIR of pyridine adsorption. Therefore, the acidity follows the order 20-Nb/TiO2 > 15-Nb/TiO2 > > 7-Nb/TiO2 > TiO2, in terms of total amount of acid sites and acid strengths, as determined by calorimetry of ammonia adsorption. This agrees with Py-FTIR results. 3.3.3 Microcalorimetry using CO2 as probe molecule The microcalorimetry experiments using CO2 as a probe molecule is a complementary analysis to measure the strength and number of base sites. The catalysts, with and without niobium, were analyzed by carbon dioxide adsorption monitored by microcalorimetry to estimate the total basicity and the distribution of base strength for the different samples ( Fig. 8). Differential heats of CO2 adsorption of the same order of magnitude, between 90 and 105 kJ.mol−1, are initially found for all samples. Thus, we can say that there are no great differences in the strength of the strongest base sites between bare TiO2 and Nb doped TiO2 samples. Probably, the strongest base sites are not directly correlated to the local Nb cations environments in contrast to the appearance of the strongest acid sites. Globally, the total number of basic sites is lower than the total number of acid sites, almost 10 time lower Fig. 7 and Fig. 8). The base sites, most likely, O2- ligands, with sufficient negative charges are less exposed on the surface than the coordinatively unsaturated metallic cations or acid hydroxyl groups. The differential heats of CO2 adsorption continuously decrease with the surface coverage for all the samples which indicates the heterogeneity of the strength of the base sites. From Table 4, it can be inferred that the pure TiO2 has the lowest number of base sites, whereas the doping with niobium enhanced the amount and strength of the base sites. There is no correlation between the BET surface area and the base sites, as all the doped samples have similar BET surface areas whereas the amount of their base sites varies by a factor of two. Also, we cannot conclude that the CO2 adsorption capacity of the solids is directly related to the amount of Nb dopant, with 20-Nb/TiO2 showing more than twice the amount of base sites of 15-Nb-TiO2. The basicity follows the order, in term of amounts of base sites and strengths: 20-Nb/TiO2 > 7-Nb/TiO2 > 15-Nb/TiO2 > TiO2. This is not in line with the acidity ranking, which is correlated with the amount of Nb. The aforesaid result can be explained by defective TiO2 anatase nanoparticles favored upon Nb doping, which may expose on the TiO2 surface, higher amounts of O2- ligands belonging to corners and edges of the nanoparticles. These O2- ligands may act as many different basic sites due to the variable negative charge carried by the oxygen atom as evidenced by the calorimetric curves. Moreover, the Nb dopant can also influence the negative charges of the superficial oxygen, which become more basic. Similarly, we cannot exclude the formation of M-OH superficial species whose negative charge of the oxygen atom, which will define the acid or basic character of the hydroxyl group, may be influenced by the nature of the metallic cation directly bonded to the OH group and by the neighboring metallic cation in case of homogenous insertion of Nb cation within the TiO2 framework. Thus, the heterogeneity of the superficial basicity of the doped and undoped TiO2 sample may have variable origins. 3.4 Catalytic evaluation in the model reaction of Dihydroxyacetone (DHA) conversion The TiO2-based catalysts were applied in the dihydroxyacetone transformation reaction in order to evaluate the impact of Nb doping on their catalytic performances to convert DHA in aqueous media. If this model reaction was largely used to probe the water tolerance of solid Lewis/Br∅nsted acid solids, known to catalyze the DHA isomerization into lactic acid via pyruvaldehyde formation [6–8], we have recently shown that a parallel pathway occurs in the presence of water tolerant base sites leading to trioses condensation into hexoses and cellobiose as shown in Scheme 1 [9]. Thus, we are expecting from the nature of the products to get insights on the water tolerance of the acid and base sites developed on the TiO2 nanoparticles upon the Nb doping. Fig. 9 shows the DHA conversion with the time course of reaction for all the TiO2 samples. The activity ranking is roughly correlated to the Nb amount: 20-Nb/TiO2 and 15-Nb/TiO2 displayed the highest DHA conversions around 90% after 4 h of reaction, followed by 7-Nb/TiO2 which presented 66% DHA conversion after 4 h. With ∼50% DHA conversion in 4 h, the pure TiO2 was the least active. Based on the initial rate of DHA conversion, the activity ranking is as follows: 20-Nb/TiO2∼15-Nb/TiO2 > 7 Nb-TiO2 > TiO2. It is clear that the catalytic activity is not related directly to the textural properties (Table 3), since the three Nb-doped TiO2, possessing quite similar BET surface areas or external surfaces and porosity, have distinct activities. Pure TiO2, which is exclusively mesoporous with a BET surface area three time lower than those of the doped catalysts, has a reduced activity of 25% only as compared to 7-Nb/TiO2. One can also observe that the two most active catalysts i.e., 15 Nb-TiO2 and 20-Nb/TiO2, are the most acid catalysts, in terms of strength and amounts of sites, but we cannot conclude that the water tolerance acidity of the TiO2-based samples is the driving force. Indeed, pure TiO2 is also active, although its surface is not acid according to the studies performed in gas phase by FTIR and calorimetry of NH3 and pyridine adsorption (Figs. 6 and 7). Fig. 10 represents the evolutions of the main products yields with the reaction progress. The differences between pure TiO2 and the Nb-doped samples is clearly seen when considering the nature of the products and their evolutions. a) TiO2, b) 7-Nb/TiO2, c) 15-Nb/TiO2 and d) 20-Nb/TiO2. Conditions: DHA (2 mmol), catalyst mass (50 mg), water (20 mL), T = 90 °C, reaction time: 4 h. For the least active sample, i.e. pure TiO2, the main primary products are PA and GA, and LA has the profile of a secondary product. These products are the expected ones when an acid catalysis pathway prevails as reported by most of the literature [6–8,14]. PA is produced from DHA dehydration. At low temperature, this step requires Br∅nsted or Lewis acid catalysts but occurs without catalysts when the temperature is higher than 100 °C [6,8]. Note that GA can be formed by a keto-enol isomerization equilibrium catalyzed as well as by Lewis acid sites or base sites [20,25,26] (Scheme 1). Lactic acid has the profile of a second product, which is in good agreement with the literature on the formation of lactic acid over Lewis acid sites. One can only undermine the apparent disagreement with our results of acid-base properties characterization in gas phase, which have shown that the sol-gel derived pure TiO2 has no acid sites strong enough to retain pyridine at 150 °C. Then the formation of PA and LA remains questionable. Besides, the GA formation can be promoted by the base sites of pure TiO2, as detected by calorimetry of CO2 adsorption. Upon doping TiO2 with the lowest amount of Nb, 7-Nb/TiO2, another family of products, fructose and glucose, appears as primary products, together with PA and GA. Cellobiose is also detected but at higher DHA conversion, rather as secondary product. We recently described that DHA conversion catalyzed by water tolerant base sites undergoes a parallel pathway via a first aldol condensation between GA and DHA to form fructose which can undergo a keto-enol isomerization over base sites into glucose. These hexoses could be further involved in a successive aldolic condensation and give cellobiose and probably other oligosaccharides. The above products distribution is in good agreement with the calorimetry results of NH3 and CO2 adsorption, which have shown that the TiO2 doping with 7 wt% Nb has created some acid sites and has enhanced more significantly the solid basicity. Increasing the amount of the Nb dopant to 15-Nb/TiO2, fructose is initially more detected than PA and the sum of the carbohydrates produced are the major products. This is an indication that in water, the surface of the doped material behaves rather as a base surface. At high DHA conversion, superior to 80%, we observe the significant increase of the formation of two secondary products, LA and cellobiose at the expense of fructose, glucose and PA. If the LA formation is usually explained by PA rehydration over Lewis acid sites, we cannot exclude the additional LA formation by C-C cleavage (retro aldol condensation) of hexoses into LA. Calorimetry of CO2 and NH3 adsorption has shown that doping TiO2 with 15 wt% of Nb has resulted in a significant enhancement of the acidity while the basicity increase was more limited and inferior to that of 7-Nb/TiO2. Moreover, Py adsorption monitored by FTIR evidenced the formation of Br∅nsted acid sites when the dopant amount achieved was 15 wt%. This seems to indicate that although the generation of new Br∅nsted acid site upon increasing the Nb dopant, this has no impact on the acid/base balance of the doped TiO2 active in water. The superficial basicity appears as the main catalytic driving force active in water. The evolution of the products yields with the reaction progress observed over 20-Nb/TiO2 consolidates this conclusion: fructose and glucose are the main primary products. Besides, the yield in cellobiose continuously increases up to the reaction end. However, we can observe again that the hexoses yield decreases when the DHA conversion overreaches 70%, slightly in favor of the C3 products: PA, GA and LA. As suggested above, these C3 products could result from hexoses C-C cleavage catalyzed by the base sites active in water. But, most likely, longer oligosaccharides, not detected by HPLC can explain the decrease in the yield of hexoses at high DHA conversion level where a lack of the carbon balance appears in parallel to the brown color of the reaction medium. Fig. 11 represents the sum of the selectivities in LA and PA, assumed to be formed by the acid catalyzed pathway, as regards to the sum of the selectivities in glucose, fructose and cellobiose, which is thought to be catalyzed by the base sites, at intermediate reaction progress, at 50% DHA conversion. This figure clearly evidences that the Nb doping favors the base-catalyzed transformation of DHA into saccharides at the expense of the acid-catalyzed reaction leading to LA and PA. This feature of the acid-base properties evolution, induced by the TiO2 doping with Nb, when probed in water via the use of the model reaction of DHA conversion, give us a different overview than the one deduced from the usual method in gas phase. In gas phase, CO2 and NH3 calorimetry combined with FTIR of pyridine adsorption show both the enhancements of the acidity and of the basicity upon Nb doping with the creation of Br∅nsted acid sites for the highest dopant loadings. In water, the Nb doping makes only the base catalytic surface active for DHA transformation. It seems that the acid sites are easily inhibited by water by contrast to the base sites which are shown to be water tolerant at least as regards to the conversion of DHA, a model molecule of more complex carbohydrates. 4 Conclusions TiO2-based catalysts doped with increasing amounts of Nb were prepared by sol-gel method using new amino alkoxides as precursors of Ti(IV) and Nb(V). The as-synthesized Nb doped TiO2 catalysts were further characterized for their structural and acid-base properties and then applied in the aqueous phase model reaction of dihydroxyacetone transformation. The anatase TiO2 phase was found for all the doped samples through X-ray diffraction and Raman spectroscopy results, without any detectable diffraction lines nor vibrations due to niobium oxide indicating an extremely high dispersion of Nb within the TiO2 matrix. Moreover, doping TiO2 with increasing amounts of Nb gave an enhancement of the amount of TiO2 defects, together with a lower degree of crystallization with particle size of 7–11 nm against ∼14 nm for undoped TiO2. The extremely high dispersion of Nb was confirmed by HR-STEM which showed the presence of Nb as isolated cation within the TiO2 matrix as well as small oxo clusters of less than 4 nm in size. Furthermore, increasing the Nb content in TiO2 not only increased the acidity as expected, but also boosted the basicity of the solid, as confirmed by the gas phase calorimetry of NH3 and CO2 adsorption. It is noteworthy that Br∅nsted acid sites are detected by gas phase FTIR of pyridine adsorption over TiO2 doped with the highest amounts of Nb, probably due to the presence of small Nb-based oxo clusters. The catalytic performances of undoped TiO2 in aqueous phase DHA transformation led to the formation of the usual products, LA, PA ad GA, which is consistent with the acid-catalyzed mechanism largely accepted in the literature. The Nb-doped TiO2 showed improved reactivity for aqueous phase DHA conversion. However, the product’s distribution, with fructose, glucose and cellobiose as main products, supports the occurrence of a base-catalyzed mechanism involving as main elementary catalytic step, aldolic condensation, leading to C6, C12 and probably longer oligosaccharides. One can conclude that doping TiO2 with increasing amounts of Nb leads to improved acid and base properties detected in gas phase, but only the base properties of the as-synthesized nanoparticles of Nb-doped TiO2 are water tolerant at least when oxygenated substrate such as DHA are employed. coredata.dc:description: Nanostructured Nb doped TiO2 were prepared by a novel Sol-Gel method using new N‐methyldiethanolamine‐modified precursors of Ti (IV) and Nb(V). Co-hydrolysis of Ti(IV) and Nb(V) precursors in suitable ratio resulted in the introduction of atomically dispersed Nb cation, along with the formation of small Nb oxo clusters homogenously dispersed within the TiO2 matrix. Characterizations showed a progressive decrease of the crystallinity as well as an increase in the defects and the BET surface areas of the TiO2 nanoparticles with the Nb doping. Upon Nb doping, gas phase calorimetry of NH3 and CO2 adsorption, evidenced the acidity but also the basicity increase. The aqueous phase dihydroxyacetone conversion increased significantly over Nb/TiO2 as compared to undoped TiO2. However, upon increasing the Nb doping, the base-catalyzed pathway, which forms hexoses from DHA, became the prevailing mechanism at the expense of the usual acid-catalyzed pathway leading to formation of Pyruvaldehyde.
coredata.dc:title: Sol-Gel controlled dispersion of Nb within TiO2 to obtain water tolerant catalysts with tunable acid-base properties for dihydroxyacetone transformation
